name: Fraction, decimal and percentage equivalence - method selection 1

skills.name: Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 2 decimal places
Convert terminating decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal places to fractions
Convert percentages containing 1 decimal place to fractions
Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages

explanations.A: Not quite! It looks as though you have combined the numerator and denominator to make the percentage but unfortunately we can't do that. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do I need to multiply 5 by to make 100?
explanations.B: We can find the percentage by multiplying 0.2 by 100, which gives 20%.
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do I need to multiply 5 by to make 100?
explanations.D: Nearly there! Remember to get from a decimal to a percentage, we need to multiply by 100. So each digit moves 2 place value columns to the left.

explanations.A: Not quite. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do I need to multiply 2 by to make 100?
explanations.B: Not quite. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do I need to multiply 2 by to make 100?
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do I need to multiply 2 by to make 100?
explanations.D: We can find the percentage by multiplying 0.5 by 100, which gives 50%.

explanations.A: Not quite. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do I need to multiply 5 by to make 100?
explanations.B: Percentages are special types of fractions with a denominator of 100. Look at the fraction 2/5: the denominator will need to be multiplied by 20 to make 100. The numerator also needs to be multiplied by 20 to keep the values in proportion: 2/5 = 40/100 = 40%.
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do I need to multiply 5 by to make 100?
explanations.D: Nearly there! Remember to get from a decimal to a percentage, we need to multiply by 100. So each digit moves 2 place value columns to the left.

explanations.A: Not quite. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do I need to multiply 5 by to make 100?
explanations.B: Not quite. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do I need to multiply 5 by to make 100?
explanations.C: Percentages are special types of fractions with a denominator of 100. Look at the fraction 3/5: the denominator will need to be multiplied by 20 to make 100. The numerator also needs to be multiplied by 20 to keep the values in proportion: 3/5 = 60/100 = 60%.
explanations.D: Nearly there! Remember to get from a decimal to a percentage, we need to multiply by 100. So each digit moves 2 place value columns to the left.

explanations.A: 0.35 means we have 3 tenths (3/10) and 5 hundredths (5/100). To add these together , we convert the 3/10 into hundredths (30/100). So 30/100 + 5/100 = 35/100. This simplifies to 7/20 by dividing the numerator and denominator by 5. So Tom is correct. Katie should have multiplied by 100 to convert from a decimal to a percentage. 0.35 should be 35%. So Katie is not correct.
explanations.B: Not quite. What do we multiply by to convert a decimal into a percentage?
explanations.C: Not quite. What do we multiply by to convert a decimal into a percentage?
explanations.D: Not quite. Try thinking of the place value of each digit in the decimal (tenths, hundredths, etc).

explanations.A: Not quite. What do we multiply by to convert a decimal into a percentage?
explanations.B: Nearly. Remember that you can simplify fractions by dividing the numerator and denominator by a common factor.
explanations.C: The 8 in 0.08 represents 8 hundredths so can be written as 8/100. This can be simplified to 2/25 so Tom is correct. To convert a decimal into a percentage, you multiply by 100. 0.08 x 100 = 8 so Katie is also correct.
explanations.D: What place value does the 8 have in 0.08? Use this information to write it as a fraction. This should help you with both Tom and Katie's calculations.

explanations.A: Not quite. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do we need to multiply 50 by to make 100?
explanations.B: "Percent" means "out of 100" so we need to change the denominator of 11/50 to 100. We can multiply the 11 and 50 by 2 so that we still have an equivalent fraction and we get 22/100. This is 22% (so Katie is correct). As a decimal, this would be 0.22 as 22/100 means 22 hundredths or 2 tenths and 2 hundredths. So Tom is incorrect.
explanations.C: Not quite. 0.11 is 11 hundredths. How would this be represented as a fraction?
explanations.D: Not quite. Remember "percent" means "out of 100". What do I need to multiply 50 by to make 100?

explanations.A: Not quite. Start by making an equivalent fraction with 100 as the denominator. We can then read off the numerator as the percentage answer
explanations.B: Not quite. Start by making an equivalent fraction with 100 as the denominator. We can then divide the numerator by 100 to get the decimal answer.
explanations.C: We need the denominator of 26/40 to be 100. First, we divide numerator and denominator by 2 to give 13/20. Then we multiply both by 5 to give 65/100 = 65 ÷ 100 = 0.65. So Jo is correct. "Percent" means "out of 100" so we can read 65/100 as 65%, so Paul is also correct.
explanations.D: Start by making an equivalent fraction with 100 as the denominator. We can then divide the numerator by 100 to get the decimal answer and read off the numerator as the percentage answer

explanations.A: Try writing 12.5% as a fraction (over 100) and then double the numerator and denominator to make them whole numbers. Now simplify your answer.
explanations.B: Nearly. Remember that to convert a percentage to a decimal, we divide by 100. That means we move each digit 2 place value columns to the right.
explanations.C: 12.5% means 12.5 out of 100, which can also be written as 12.5/100 = 12.5 ÷ 100 = 0.125. So Tom is correct. Katie is also correct because 12.5/100 = 25/200 if we multiply the numerator and denominator by 2. This simplifies to ⅛.
explanations.D: Try writing 12.5% as a fraction (over 100) to see if Tom is correct. You can then divide the numerator by 100 to get the decimal answer. Try using equivalent fractions to see whether Katie is correct.

explanations.A: Try writing 5.5% as a fraction (over 100) and then double the numerator and denominator to make them whole numbers. Now simplify your answer.
explanations.B: Nearly. Remember that to convert a percentage to a decimal, we divide by 100. That means we move each digit 2 place value columns to the right.
explanations.C: 5.5% means 5.5 out of 100, which can also be written as 5.5/100 = 5.5 ÷ 100 = 0.055. So Jo is correct. Paul is also correct because 5.5/100 = 11/200 if we multiply the numerator and denominator by 2.
explanations.D: Try writing 5.5% as a fraction (over 100) to see if Jo is correct. You can then divide the numerator by 100 to get the decimal answer. Try using equivalent fractions to see whether Paul is correct.
